title: Statistical Analysis of Southern California Weather Variables
text: Data Source

title: Statistical Analysis of Southern California Weather Variables
section: 1. Geographic locations effect to level of Temperature
text:
1. Geographic locations effect to level of Temperature
%%R
oneway.test(Temperature ~ County,
  data = subset,
  var.equal = FALSE # assuming unequal variances - Welch Anova
)

One-way analysis of means (not assuming equal variances)


data: Temperature and County F = 850.85, num df = 8, denom df = 15015, p-value < 2.2e-16

%%R
aov(Temperature ~ County, data = subset) %>% 
  report()

The ANOVA (formula: Temperature ~ County) suggests that: The main effect of County is statistically significant and large (F(8, 36153) = 1088.27, p < .001; Eta2 = 0.19, 95% CI [0.19, 1.00]) Effect sizes were labelled following Field’s (2013) recommendations.

title: Statistical Analysis of Southern California Weather Variables
section: 2. Geographic locations effect to level of Relative Humidity
text:
2. Geographic locations effect to level of Relative Humidity
%%R
oneway.test(subset$'Relative Humidity' ~ County,
  data = subset,
  var.equal = FALSE # assuming unequal variances - Welch Anova
)

One-way analysis of means (not assuming equal variances)


data: subset$“Relative Humidity” and County F = 2611.5, num df = 8, denom df = 15050, p-value < 2.2e-16

%%R
aov(subset$'Relative Humidity' ~ County, data = subset) %>% 
  report()

The ANOVA (formula: subset$“Relative Humidity” ~ County) suggests that: The main effect of County is statistically significant and large (F(8, 36153) = 2333.44, p < .001; Eta2 = 0.34, 95% CI [0.36, 1.00]) Effect sizes were labelled following Field’s (2013) recommendations.

title: Statistical Analysis of Southern California Weather Variables
section: 3. Geographic locations effect to level of Cloud Cover
text:
3. Geographic locations effect to level of Cloud Cover
%%R
oneway.test(subset$'Cloud Cover' ~ County,
  data = subset,
  var.equal = FALSE # assuming unequal variances - Welch Anova
)

One-way analysis of means (not assuming equal variances)


data: subset$“Cloud Cover” and County F = 2076.3, num df = 8, denom df = 14927, p-value < 2.2e-16

%%R
aov(subset$'Cloud Cover' ~ County, data = subset) %>% 
  report()

The ANOVA (formula: subset$“Cloud Cover” ~ County) suggests that: The main effect of County is statistically significant and large (F(8, 36153) = 1029.98, p < .001; Eta2 = 0.19, 95% CI [0.18, 1.00]) Effect sizes were labelled following Field’s (2013) recommendations.

title: Statistical Analysis of Southern California Weather Variables
section: 4. Geographic locations effect to level of Wind Direction
text:
4. Geographic locations effect to level of Wind Direction
%%R
oneway.test(subset$'Wind Direction' ~ County,
  data = subset,
  var.equal = FALSE )
# assuming unequal variances - Welch Anova

One-way analysis of means (not assuming equal variances)


data: subset$“Wind Direction” and County F = 669.95, num df = 8, denom df = 15052, p-value < 2.2e-16

%%R
aov(subset$'Wind Direction' ~ County, data = subset) %>% 
  report()

The ANOVA (formula: subset$“Wind Direction” ~ County) suggests that: The main effect of County is statistically significant and medium (F(8, 36153) = 635.74, p < .001; Eta2 = 0.12, 95% CI [0.12, 1.00]) Effect sizes were labelled following Field’s (2013) recommendations.

from mitosheet import *; register_analysis("id-ptawblnkug");
    
# Added column new-column-q0fm
df_fire.insert(1, 'new-column-q0fm', 0)

# Set formula of new-column-q0fm
df_fire['new-column-q0fm'] = YEAR(df_fire['Started'])

# Renamed columns Year
df_fire.rename(columns={'new-column-q0fm': 'Year'}, inplace=True)

# Added column new-column-epid
df_fire.insert(2, 'new-column-epid', 0)

# Set formula of new-column-epid
df_fire['new-column-epid'] = MONTH(df_fire['Started'])

# Renamed columns Month
df_fire.rename(columns={'new-column-epid': 'Month'}, inplace=True)

# Added column new-column-zudb
df_fire.insert(4, 'new-column-zudb', 0)

# Reordered column new-column-zudb
df_fire_columns = [col for col in df_fire.columns if col != 'new-column-zudb']
df_fire_columns.insert(3, 'new-column-zudb')
df_fire = df_fire[df_fire_columns]

# Set formula of new-column-zudb
df_fire['new-column-zudb'] = DAY(df_fire['Started'])

# Renamed columns Day
df_fire.rename(columns={'new-column-zudb': 'Day'}, inplace=True)

## Import Library
import rpy2.robjects as robjects
%load_ext rpy2.ipython

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
import math

import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

%R require(tidyverse)
%R require(DataExplorer)
%R require(readxl)
%R require(weathermetrics)
%R require(flextable)
%R options(warn=-1)

#combine data
df1 = pd.read_excel("2010_weather_dataset.xlsx")
df2 = pd.read_excel("2011_weather_dataset.xlsx")
df3 = pd.read_excel("2012_weather_dataset.xlsx")
df4 = pd.read_excel("2013_weather_dataset.xlsx")
df5 = pd.read_excel("2014_weather_dataset.xlsx")
df6 = pd.read_excel("2015_weather_dataset.xlsx")
df7 = pd.read_excel("2016_weather_dataset.xlsx")
df8 = pd.read_excel("2017_weather_dataset.xlsx")
df9 = pd.read_excel("2018_weather_dataset.xlsx")
df10 = pd.read_excel("2019_weather_dataset.xlsx")
df11 = pd.read_excel("2020_weather_dataset.xlsx")

# Read CSV files from List
df = pd.concat([df1,df2,df3,df4,df5,df6,df7,df8,df9,df10,df11])

# Create New variables
df['Year'] = pd.DatetimeIndex(df['Date time']).year
df['Month'] = pd.DatetimeIndex(df['Date time']).month
df['Day'] = pd.DatetimeIndex(df['Date time']).day
df[["County","State","Country"]] = df["Name"].str.split(pat=',',expand=True, n = 2)

# Drop Columns with Null Values
df = df.drop(['Heat Index','Wind Chill','Snow','Snow Depth','Wind Gust'], axis=1)

# Filtered County
df_south = df[df['County'].apply(lambda val: all(val != s for s in ['Yuba City', 'Yolo', 'Tuolumne', 'Tulare', 'Trinity', 'Tehama', 'Sutter', 'Stanislaus', 'Sonoma', 'Solano', 'Siskiyou', 'Sierra City', 'Shasta', 'Santa Cruz', 'Santa Clara', 'San Mateo', 'San Joaquín', 'San Joaquin', 'San Francisco', 'San Benito', 'Sacramento', 'Plumas', 'Placer', 'Nevada City', 'Napa', 'Monterey', 'Mono', 'Modoc', 'Merced', 'Mendocino', 'Mariposa', 'Marin', 'Madera', 'Lassen', 'Lake City', 'Inyo', 'Humboldt', 'Glenn', 'Fresno', 'El Dorado', 'Del Norte', 'County Line Rd', 'Contra Costa', 'Colusa', 'California City', 'California', 'Calaveras', 'Butte City', 'Amador City', 'Alpine', 'Alameda']))]

title: Calculate Heat Index of Southern California
text:
Heat Index by Month

1. January


Show the code
index_jan = df_map[['County','Heat Index median 1.0','geometry']]
bins = [0, 79.999, 89.999, 102.999, 124.999, 999.999]
group_names = ['Normal','Caution','Extreme Caution','Danger','Extreme Danger']
index_jan['Status'] = pd.cut(index_jan['Heat Index median 1.0'], bins, labels=group_names)

plt.style.use('ggplot')
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(20, 10))
index_jan.plot(ax=ax, column='Heat Index median 1.0',cmap='YlOrRd',legend=True)
index_jan.apply(lambda x: ax.annotate(text=x['Status'], xy=x.geometry.centroid.coords[0], ha='center'), axis=1)
plt.title("January Heat Index", fontsize=16);

title: Weather Detective in Actions
text:
Ventura County have the highest amount of burned areas with 428,304 AcresBurned from 17 incidents. On the otherside Riverside County had 97,362 AcresBurned from 133 incidents. AverageBurned per incident in Ventura County is 25,194 Acres, and Riverside County is 732 Acres. Reference link



High frequency of wildfires occured on May to October with the maximum frequency happened on July. Medium Frequency of wildfires occured on April, November and December. Low Frequency of wildfires occured from January to March, January seems to be the most save month from wildfire. Reference Link



How does lightning form? see Reference Link. What we can do is understand the weather patterns and pay attention about the vegetation.

title: Weather Conditions in Southern California From Different Level of Risks
text:
We are using Weather Dataset on 2010 -2020 that are already being cleaned on previous process.See for Reference. And then we catogorized the data into 3 level of Risk: High,Medium and Low for comparison purpose, see for Reference. We do comparison between Low and High level of risk for the clarity of the differentiation.
We are removing Imperial County from the parameter because Imperial County do not have wildfire incident on the incident data, see for Reference
